item.title: subrun
item.description: subrun - Run the currently open file in Sublime. SYNOPSIS subrun [-v|-h] DESCRIPTION subrun makes the currently open file in sublime executable and runs it with eval. OPTIONS -v Show version and exit. -h Show help and exit. DEPENDENCIES subtit sublime

item.title: subtit
item.description: subtit subtit - Output the currently open file in sublime. SYNOPSIS subtit [-v|-h|-l] DESCRIPTION subtit uses i3get to get the window title of Sublime Text. It extracts the filename from the title and prints it to stdout. If -l flag is passed subtit will follow symbolic links if any and print the source file. OPTIONS -v Show version and exit. -h Show help and exit. -l Follow symbolic links.

item.title: subpro
item.description: subpro subpro - Switch sublime projects SYNOPSIS subpro [-v|-h] project-nane DESCRIPTION subpro closes the currently open project in Sublime Text and opens project-name in it’s place. OPTIONS -v Show version and exit. -h Show help and exit. FILES FLD_PRO Folder containing .sublime-project files defaults to: ~/tmp/kortisar/sublime/projects DEPENDENCIES SublimeText

item.title: budtutor
item.description: budtutor budtutor - Interactive tutorial for Sublime Text SYNOPSIS budtutor [OPTION] DESCRIPTION Interactive tutorial for sublime text. It is a mashup of vimtutor and sublime tutor. If executed without options, the whole budtutor will be opened in sublime text. OPTIONS -h Displays this info and exits -v Displays version and exits -s Shows ‘sublime’ exercises -m Shows ‘vim’ exercises -p Shows ‘packages’ exercises -c Compact view, only exercise and command

item.title: suba
item.description: This is a script I wrote to automate the process of uploading scripts and dotfiles to this web site. It analyzes the title of Sublime Text to get the filename of the currently open file. If the file is in ~/bin (my local scripfolder), it is a scriptfile, else it is a dotfile. Depending on the type it is sent to different directories within my hugo project folder. Which is on my Dropbox.
